chapter.title: Subscription Management
chapter.para: Any machine running &sls; 11 or &sled; 11 can be configured to register against local &smtool; server to download software updates instead of communicating directly with the &ncc; and the ν servers. To use an ⪪ server for client registration and as a local update source, you must configure the ⪪ server in your network first. The ⪪ server software is distributed as an add-on for &sls; and its configuration is described in the &smtguide;. There is no need to install any add-on on the clients to be configured for registering against an ⪪ server.

To register a client against an ⪪ server, you need to equip the client with the server's URL. As client and server communicate via the HTTPS protocol during registration, you also need to make sure the client trusts the server's certificate. In case your ⪪ server is set up to use the default server certificate, the CA certificate will be available on the ⪪ server via HTTP protocol at http://FQDN/smt.crt. In this case you do not have to concern yourself with the certificate: the registration process will automatically download the CA certificate from there, unless configured otherwise. You must enter a path to the server's CA certificate if the certificate was issued by an external certificate authority.

note.title: Registering Against *.novell.com Subdomain
note.para: If you try to register against any *.novell.com subdomain, the certificate will not be downloaded during registration (for security reasons), and certificate handling will not be done. In such cases, use a different domain name or a plain IP address.

chapter.para: There are several ways to provide this information and to configure the client machine to use ⪪. The first way is to provide the needed information via kernel parameters at boot time. The second way is to configure clients using an &ay; profile. There is also a script distributed with &smtool;, clientSetup4SMT.sh, which can be run on a client to make it register against a specified ⪪ server. These methods are described in the following sections:

sect1.title: Using Kernel Parameters to Access an ⪪ Server
sect1.para: Any client can be configured to use ⪪ by providing the following kernel parameters during machine boot: regurl and regcert. The first parameter is mandatory, the latter is optional.

listitem.para: URL of the ⪪ server. The URL needs to be in the following format: https://FQDN/center/regsvc/ with FQDN being the fully qualified hostname of the ⪪ server. It must be identical to the FQDN of the server certificate used on the ⪪ server. Example:

warning.title: Beware of Typing Errors
warning.para: Make sure the values you enter are correct. If regurl has not been specified correctly, the registration of the update source will fail.

If a wrong value for regcert has been entered, you will be prompted for a local path to the certificate. In case regcert is not specified at all, it will default to http://FQDN/smt.crt with FQDN being the name of the ⪪ server.

warning.title: Change of ⪪ Server Certificate
warning.para: If the ⪪ server gets a new certificate from a new and untrusted CA, the clients need to fetch the new CA certificate file. This is done automatically with the registration process but only if a URL was used at installation time to retrieve the certificate, or if the regcert parameter was omitted and thus, the default URL is used. If the certificate was loaded using any other method (such as local path), the CA certificate will not be updated.

sect1.title: Configuring Clients Using &ay; Profile
sect1.para: Clients can be configured to register with ⪪ server via &ay; profile. For general information about creating &ay; profiles and preparing automatic installation, refer to . In this section, only ⪪ specific configuration is described.
To configure ⪪ specific data using &ay;, follow these steps:

step.para: As &rootuser;, start &yast; and select Miscellaneous Autoinstallation to start the graphical &ay; front-end.
From a command line, you can start the graphical &ay; front-end with the yast2 autoyast command.
Open an existing profile using FileOpen, create a profile based on the current system's configuration using ToolsCreate Reference Profile, or just work with an empty profile.
Select SupportNovell Customer Center Configuration. An overview of the current configuration is shown.
To register while installing automatically, select Run Product Registration. You can include information from your system with Hardware Profile and Optional Information.

Set the URL of the ⪪ Server and, optionally, the location of the ⪪ Certificate. The possible values are the same as for the kernel parameters regurl and regcert (see ). The only exception is that the ask value for regcert does not work in &ay;, because it requires user interaction. If using it, the registration process will be skipped.
Perform all other configuration needed for the systems to be deployed.
Select File Save As and enter a filename for the profile, such as autoinst.xml.

sect1.title: Configuring Clients Using the clientSetup4SMT.sh Script
sect1.para: The /usr/share/doc/packages/smt/clientSetup4SMT.sh script is provided with ⪪. This script allows to configure a client machine to use a ⪪ server or to reconfigure it to use a different ⪪ server.
To configure a client machine to use ⪪ with the clientSetup4SMT.sh script, follow these steps:

step.para: Copy the /usr/share/doc/packages/smt/clientSetup4SMT.sh script from your ⪪ server to the client machine.

As &rootuser;, execute the script on the client machine. The script can be executed in two ways. In the first case, the script name is followed by the registration URL: ./clientSetup4SMT.sh registration_URL, for example, ./clientSetup4SMT.sh https://smt.&exampledomain;/center/regsvc. In the second case, the script name is followed by the --host option followed by hostname of the ⪪ server: ./clientSetup4SMT.sh --host server_hostname, for example, ./clientSetup4SMT.sh --host smt.&exampledomain;.

important.title: The --host Parameter
important.para: The hostname that needs to be provided with the --host parameter, needs to be the same name the certificate is issued for. Furthermore, if the name in the certificate is the fully qualified hostname (e.g. smt.&exampledomain;), it needs to be entered as such—entering the short name (smt) will cause the clientSetup4SMT.sh script to fail.

step.para: The script downloads the server's CA certificate. Accept it by pressing y.
The script performs all necessary modifications on the client. However, the registration itself is not performed by the script.
Perform a registration by executing suse_register or running yast2 inst_suse_register module on the client.
